Stars are set up for him after he dies, so everything’s allowed. But honestly, these people feel more like bronze than flesh! 

A wild thought hit him, and he almost laughed. Napoleon, the pyramids, Waterloo, and a scrawny old pawnbroker with a red trunk under her bed—it’s such a weird mix for Porfiry Petrovitch to deal with! How can he even handle that? It’s just too messy. ‘A Napoleon hiding under an old woman’s bed? Gross!’

Sometimes he felt like he was losing it. He was in a feverish state of excitement. ‘That old woman doesn’t matter,’ he thought, heated and jumbled. ‘She was a mistake, sure, but she’s not the point! She was just an illness… I rushed to overstep… I didn’t kill a person, I killed a principle! I took out the principle, but I didn’t really overstep; I stopped short… I could only kill. And it seems I couldn’t even do that… Principle? Why was that idiot Razumihin trashing the socialists? They’re hardworking, business-minded folks; ‘the happiness of all’ is their goal. Nah, I only get one shot at life, and I won’t wait for ‘the happiness of all.’ I want to live now, or not at all. I couldn’t just ignore my starving mother, keeping my rouble while I wait for ‘the happiness of all.’ I’m putting my little brick into that happiness, so my heart feels at peace. Ha-ha! Why have you let me slip away? I only live once, I want… Ech, I’m just an aesthetic louse, nothing more,’ he suddenly laughed, sounding a bit insane. ‘Yeah, I’m definitely a louse,’ he continued, grabbing onto that idea, relishing it, and playing with it like a cat with a toy.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov grapples with his justifications for murder, questioning the value of his actions and the principles behind them.
